trans-unit.source: Mutiple VIPs per cloud service
trans-unit.target: Mutiple VIPs per cloud service

trans-unit.source: Overview of multiVIP and how to set multiple VIPs on a cloud service
trans-unit.target: Overview of multiVIP and how to set multiple VIPs on a cloud service

trans-unit.source: You can access Azure cloud services over the public Internet by using an IP address provided by Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can access Azure cloud services over the public Internet by using an IP address provided by Azure.

trans-unit.source: This public IP address is referred to as a VIP (virtual IP) since it is linked to the Azure load balancer, and not really the VM instances within the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This public IP address is referred to as a VIP (virtual IP) since it is linked to the Azure load balancer, and not really the VM instances within the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You can access any VM instance within a cloud service by using a single VIP.
trans-unit.target: You can access any VM instance within a cloud service by using a single VIP.

trans-unit.source: However, there are scenarios in which you may need more than one VIP as an entry point to the same cloud service.
trans-unit.target: However, there are scenarios in which you may need more than one VIP as an entry point to the same cloud service.

trans-unit.source: For instance, your cloud service may host multiple websites that requires SSL connectivity using the default SLSL port of 443, each site being hosted for a different customer, or tenant.
trans-unit.target: For instance, your cloud service may host multiple websites that requires SSL connectivity using the default SLSL port of 443, each site being hosted for a different customer, or tenant.

trans-unit.source: In such a scenario, you need to have a different public facing IP address for each website.
trans-unit.target: In such a scenario, you need to have a different public facing IP address for each website.

trans-unit.source: The diagram below shows a typical multi-tenant web hosting with a need for multiple SSL certificates on the same public port.
trans-unit.target: The diagram below shows a typical multi-tenant web hosting with a need for multiple SSL certificates on the same public port.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Multi VIP SSL scenario</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Multi VIP SSL scenario</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the above scenario, all VIPs use the same public port (443) and traffic is redirected to one or more load balanced VMs on a unique private port for the internal IP address of the cloud service hosting all the websites.
trans-unit.target: In the above scenario, all VIPs use the same public port (443) and traffic is redirected to one or more load balanced VMs on a unique private port for the internal IP address of the cloud service hosting all the websites.

trans-unit.source: Another scenario for the use the multiple VIPs is hosting multiple SQL AlwaysOn availability group listeners on the same set of Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: Another scenario for the use the multiple VIPs is hosting multiple SQL AlwaysOn availability group listeners on the same set of Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: VIPs are dynamic by default, which means that the actual IP address assigned to the cloud service may change over time.
trans-unit.target: VIPs are dynamic by default, which means that the actual IP address assigned to the cloud service may change over time.

trans-unit.source: To prevent that from happening, you can reserve a VIP for your service.
trans-unit.target: To prevent that from happening, you can reserve a VIP for your service.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about reserved VIPs, see <linkText>Reserved Public IP</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about reserved VIPs, see <linkText>Reserved Public IP</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Please see <linkText>IP Address pricing</linkText><title></title> for information on pricing on VIPs and reserved IPs.
trans-unit.target: Please see <linkText>IP Address pricing</linkText><title></title> for information on pricing on VIPs and reserved IPs.

trans-unit.source: You can use PowerShell to verify the VIPs used by your cloud services, as well as add and remove VIPs, associate a VIP to an endpoint, and configure load balancing on a specific VIP.
trans-unit.target: You can use PowerShell to verify the VIPs used by your cloud services, as well as add and remove VIPs, associate a VIP to an endpoint, and configure load balancing on a specific VIP.

trans-unit.source: At this time, multi VIP functionality is limited to the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: At this time, multi VIP functionality is limited to the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: IaaS only.
trans-unit.target: IaaS only.

trans-unit.source: You can only enable multi VIP for cloud services that contain VMs.
trans-unit.target: You can only enable multi VIP for cloud services that contain VMs.

trans-unit.source: You cannot use multi VIP in PaaS scenarios, with role instances.
trans-unit.target: You cannot use multi VIP in PaaS scenarios, with role instances.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell only.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell only.

trans-unit.source: You can only manage multi VIP by using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can only manage multi VIP by using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: These limitations are temporary, and may change at any time.
trans-unit.target: These limitations are temporary, and may change at any time.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to revisit this page to verify future changes.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to revisit this page to verify future changes.

trans-unit.source: You can only remove a VIP if it has no endpoints associated to it.
trans-unit.target: You can only remove a VIP if it has no endpoints associated to it.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the VIPs associated with a cloud service, run the following PowerShell script:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the VIPs associated with a cloud service, run the following PowerShell script:

trans-unit.source: The script above will display a result similar to the sample below:
trans-unit.target: The script above will display a result similar to the sample below:

trans-unit.source: In this example, the cloud service has 3 VIPs:
trans-unit.target: In this example, the cloud service has 3 VIPs:

trans-unit.source: Vip1 is the default VIP, you know that because the value for IsDnsProgrammedName is set to true.
trans-unit.target: Vip1 is the default VIP, you know that because the value for IsDnsProgrammedName is set to true.

trans-unit.source: Vip2 and Vip3 are not used as they don’t have any IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: Vip2 and Vip3 are not used as they don’t have any IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: They will only be used if you associate an endpoint to the VIP.
trans-unit.target: They will only be used if you associate an endpoint to the VIP.

trans-unit.source: Your subscription will only be charged for extra VIPs once they are associated with an endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Your subscription will only be charged for extra VIPs once they are associated with an endpoint.

trans-unit.source: For more information on pricing, see <linkText>IP Address pricing</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on pricing, see <linkText>IP Address pricing</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To associate a VIP on a cloud service to an endpoint, run the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To associate a VIP on a cloud service to an endpoint, run the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: The command above creates an endpoint linked to the VIP called Vip2 on port 80, and links it to the VM named myVM1 in a cloud service named myService using TCP on port 8080.
trans-unit.target: The command above creates an endpoint linked to the VIP called Vip2 on port 80, and links it to the VM named myVM1 in a cloud service named myService using TCP on port 8080.

trans-unit.source: To verify the configuration, run the following PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: To verify the configuration, run the following PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: And the output will look similar to the results below:
trans-unit.target: And the output will look similar to the results below:

trans-unit.source: You can associate a single VIP with multiple virtual machines for load balancing purposes.
trans-unit.target: You can associate a single VIP with multiple virtual machines for load balancing purposes.

trans-unit.source: For instance, suppose you have a cloud service named myService, and two virtual machines named myVM1 and myVM2.
trans-unit.target: For instance, suppose you have a cloud service named myService, and two virtual machines named myVM1 and myVM2.

trans-unit.source: And your cloud service has multiple VIPs, one of them named Vip2.
trans-unit.target: And your cloud service has multiple VIPs, one of them named Vip2.

trans-unit.source: If you want to ensure that all traffic to port 81 on Vip2 is balanced between myVM1 and myVM2 on port 8181, run the following PowerShell script:
trans-unit.target: If you want to ensure that all traffic to port 81 on Vip2 is balanced between myVM1 and myVM2 on port 8181, run the following PowerShell script:

trans-unit.source: You can also update your load balancer to use a different VIP.
trans-unit.target: You can also update your load balancer to use a different VIP.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you run the PowerShell command below, you will change the load balancing set to use a VIP named Vip1:
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you run the PowerShell command below, you will change the load balancing set to use a VIP named Vip1:
